page.title: 01Dyffryn Anafon and the Hills
page.content: The area is bisected by Afon Anafon (in a classic glaciated valley) which starts from Llyn Anafon, a natural lake used by Welsh Water Authority to supply coastal towns to the north. To the N and E is a ridge ending at the highest peak, Y Drum in the SE corner of the area; the ridge is also the boundary of National Trust land to the west. A rough vehicle track leads south from lower levels to the summit of Y Drum. A similar track leads to the lake. The whole area is rough grazing for countless sheep and some wild ponies. Many farms have sheep ranges here. Some of the range boundaries are fenced. The grazing of the sheep prevents growth of any vegetation besides grasses and some low shrubs such as heather.
